company.name: James B. Nutter & Company
company.business_description: James B. Nutter & Company makes and services single-family residential mortgage loans throughout the United States. The company routinely collects sensitive personal information from consumers in connection with its lending business.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 501(b) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (15 U.S.C. § 6801(b)) and Sections 501-509 of the GLB Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6809); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 314) and Privacy of Customer Financial Information Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 313)

complaint.factual_background: James B. Nutter & Company, a mortgage lender, collected sensitive personal information from consumers including Social Security numbers, bank account numbers, and credit histories. From September 2004 to November 2008, the company failed to implement reasonable data security measures and provided inadequate privacy notices to customers. An intruder was able to exploit these security failures to direct the company's network to send millions of spam emails and could have accessed personal information without authorization.

representations_made.description: Provided privacy notices that did not set out the company's security practices
representations_made.quoted_text: The notices it provided: (1) did not set out respondent's security practices

representations_made.description: Privacy notices did not accurately inform customers about disclosures to third parties
representations_made.quoted_text: did not accurately inform customers that respondent disclosed customer information to third parties, such as credit reporting agencies

representations_made.description: Privacy notices incorrectly stated customers had only 30 days to opt out
representations_made.quoted_text: informed customers that they had 30 days in which to exercise their opt-out rights, even though the Privacy Rule provides that they can opt out at any time during the course of their loans

counts.title: Violations of the Safeguards Rule
counts.representation: Respondent was required as a financial institution to implement reasonable security policies and procedures including a comprehensive written information security program, risk assessment, safeguard design and testing, and service provider oversight
counts.fact: Respondent failed to develop a comprehensive written information security program; failed to identify reasonably foreseeable risks; failed to design, implement, and test safeguards; failed to investigate and adjust the security program; and failed to require service providers by contract to implement safeguards
counts.conclusion: Respondent engaged in violations of the Safeguards Rule.

counts.title: Violations of the Privacy Rule
counts.representation: Respondent was required to provide customers with privacy notices that set out security practices, accurately described disclosures to third parties, and accurately informed customers of their opt-out rights
counts.fact: Respondent failed to provide privacy notices for several years after the Rule became effective, and thereafter provided notices that failed to set out security practices, did not accurately describe disclosures to third parties, and incorrectly informed customers they had only 30 days to exercise opt-out rights when they could opt out at any time

definitions.Personal information: individually identifiable information from or about an individual consumer including, but not limited to: (a) a first and last name; (b) a home or other physical address, including street name and name of city or town; (c) an email address or other online contact information, such as an instant messaging user identifier or a screen name; (d) a telephone number; (e) a Social Security number; (f) a driver's license number; (g) a bank, loan, mortgage, credit card, or debit card account number; (h) a persistent identifier, such as a customer number held in a "cookie" or processor serial number, that is combined with other available data that identifies an individual consumer; or (i) any information that is combined with any of (a) through (h) above.
definitions.Respondent: James B. Nutter & Company and its subsidiaries, divisions, and affiliates, and successors and assigns.
definitions.Commerce: as defined in Section 4 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 44.

provisions.title: Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers.

requirements.description: Establish and implement comprehensive information security program
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS ORDERED that respondent, and its officers, agents, representatives, and employees, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, or other device, in connection with the advertising, marketing, promotion, offering for sale, or sale of any product or service, in or affecting commerce, shall, no later than the date of service of this order, establish and implement, and thereafter maintain, a comprehensive information security program that is reasonably designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers.
requirements.deadline: no later than the date of service of this order

requirements.description: Designate employee(s) to coordinate and be accountable for the information security program
requirements.quoted_text: the designation of an employee or employees to coordinate and be accountable for the information security program

requirements.description: Identify material internal and external risks to personal information and assess sufficiency of safeguards
requirements.quoted_text: the identification of material internal and external risks to the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information that could result in the unauthorized disclosure, misuse, loss, alteration, destruction, or other compromise of such information, and assessment of the sufficiency of any safeguards in place to control these risks. At a minimum, this risk assessment should include consideration of risks in each area of relevant operation, including, but not limited to: (1) employee training and management; (2) information systems, including network and software design, information processing, storage, transmission, and disposal; and (3) prevention, detection, and response to attacks, intrusions, or other systems failures

requirements.description: Design and implement reasonable safeguards to control identified risks and regularly test or monitor effectiveness
requirements.quoted_text: the design and implementation of reasonable safeguards to control the risks identified through risk assessment and regular testing or monitoring of the effectiveness of the safeguards' key controls, systems, and procedures

requirements.description: Take reasonable steps to select and retain service providers capable of safeguarding personal information and require them by contract to implement safeguards
requirements.quoted_text: the development and use of reasonable steps to select and retain service providers capable of appropriately safeguarding personal information they receive from respondent, and requiring service providers by contract to implement and maintain appropriate safeguards

requirements.description: Evaluate and adjust information security program based on testing, monitoring, and changes to operations
requirements.quoted_text: the evaluation and adjustment of respondent's information security program in light of the results of the testing and monitoring required by sub-Part C, any material changes to respondent's operations or business arrangements, or any other circumstances that respondent knows or has reason to know may have a material impact on the effectiveness of respondent's information security program.

provisions.title: Compliance with Gramm-Leach-Bliley Rules
provisions.summary: Respondent must not violate the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule or the Privacy of Customer Financial Information Rule.

requirements.description: Must not violate the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent, and its officers, agents, representatives, and employees, shall not, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, or other device, violate any provision of: A. the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

requirements.description: Must not violate the Privacy of Customer Financial Information Rule
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent, and its officers, agents, representatives, and employees, shall not, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, or other device, violate any provision of: B. the Privacy of Customer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313.

provisions.title: Third-Party Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of its information security program for ten years after service of the order.

requirements.description: Obtain initial assessment covering first 180 days after service of order
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, in connection with its compliance with Parts I and IIA of this order, respondent, and its officers, agents, representatives, and employees, shall obtain initial and biennial assessments and reports ("Assessments") from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional, who uses procedures and standards generally accepted in the profession. The reporting period for the Assessments shall cover: (1) the first one hundred and eighty (180) days after service of the order for the initial Assessment

requirements.description: Obtain biennial assessments covering each two-year period for ten years after service of order
requirements.quoted_text: The reporting period for the Assessments shall cover: (2) each two (2) year period thereafter for ten (10) years after service of the order for the biennial Assessments.

requirements.description: Each assessment must be completed within 60 days after the end of the reporting period
requirements.quoted_text: Each Assessment shall be prepared and completed within sixty (60) days after the end of the reporting period to which the Assessment applies by a person qualified as a Certified Information System Security Professional (CISSP) or as a Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA); a person holding Global Information Assurance Certification (GIAC) from the SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security (SANS) Institute; or a similarly qualified person or organization approved by the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, Washington, D.C. 20580.
requirements.deadline: 60 days after end of reporting period

requirements.description: Provide initial assessment to FTC within 10 days after preparation
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall provide the initial Assessment to the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, Washington, D.C. 20580, within ten (10) days after the Assessment has been prepared.

requirements.description: Retain all subsequent biennial assessments and provide to FTC within 10 days of request
requirements.quoted_text: All subsequent biennial Assessments shall be retained by respondent until the order is terminated and provided to the Associate Director for Enforcement within ten (10) days of request.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC various compliance-related documents for specified periods.

requirements.description: Maintain for 5 years documents relating to compliance with the order
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall maintain, and upon request, make available to the Federal Trade Commission for inspection and copying: A. for a period of five (5) years, a print or electronic copy of each document relating to compliance, including but not limited to documents, prepared by or on behalf of respondent that contradict, qualify, or call into question respondent's compliance with this order

requirements.description: Maintain for 3 years after each assessment all materials relied upon to prepare the assessment
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall maintain, and upon request, make available to the Federal Trade Commission for inspection and copying: B. for a period of three (3) years after the date of preparation of each Assessment required under Part III of this order, all materials relied upon to prepare the Assessment, whether prepared by or on behalf of respondent, including but not limited to all plans, reports, studies, reviews, audits, audit trails, policies, training materials, and assessments, and any other materials relating to respondent's compliance with Parts I and IIA of this order, for the compliance period covered by such Assessment.

provisions.title: Order Distribution and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of the order to all current and future personnel with relevant responsibilities.

requirements.description: Deliver order to current personnel within 30 days after service of order
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current and future employees, agents, and representatives having responsibilities relating to the subject matter of this order. Respondent shall deliver this order to such current personnel within thirty (30) days after service of this order

requirements.description: Deliver order to future personnel within 30 days after they assume relevant position or responsibilities
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current and future employees, agents, and representatives having responsibilities relating to the subject matter of this order. Respondent shall deliver this order to such future personnel within thirty (30) days after the person assumes such position or responsibilities.

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations.

requirements.description: Notify Commission at least 30 days prior to corporate changes affecting compliance obligations
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any change in the company that may affect compliance obligations arising under this order, including, but not limited to, a dissolution, assignment, sale, merger, or other action that would result in the emergence of a successor company; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, or affiliate that engages in any acts or practices subject to this order; the proposed filing of a bankruptcy petition; or a change in the company name or address.

requirements.description: If less than 30 days notice of change, notify Commission as soon as practicable after obtaining knowledge
requirements.quoted_text: Provided, however, that, with respect to any proposed change in the company about which respondent learns less than thirty (30) days prior to the date such action is to take place, respondent shall notify the Commission as soon as is practicable after obtaining such knowledge.

provisions.title: Compliance Reports
provisions.summary: Respondent must file written compliance reports with the Commission within 60 days after service of the order and at other times as required.

requirements.description: File compliance report within 60 days after service of order and at other times as FTC may require
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall, within sixty (60) days after service of this order, and at such other times as the Federal Trade Commission may require, file with the Commission a report, in writing, setting forth in detail the manner and form in which it has complied with this order.

provisions.title: Order Termination
provisions.summary: This order terminates on June 12, 2029, or 20 years from the most recent date the U.S. or FTC files a complaint in federal court alleging violation of the order, whichever comes later.

requirements.description: Order terminates on specified date or 20 years from most recent federal court complaint, whichever is later
requirements.quoted_text: This order will terminate on June 12, 2029, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Federal Trade Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later

duration.termination_text: This order will terminate on June 12, 2029, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Federal Trade Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. any Part in this order that terminates in less than twenty (20) years; B. this order's application to any respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. this order if such complaint is filed after the order has terminated pursuant to this Part. Provided, further, that if such complaint is dismissed or a federal court rules that respondent did not violate any provision of the order, and the dismissal or ruling is either not appealed or upheld on appeal, then the order will terminate according to this Part as though the complaint had never been filed, except that the order will not terminate between the date such complaint is filed and the later of the deadline for appealing such dismissal or ruling and the date such dismissal or ruling is upheld on appeal.
